title-group.article-title: An adaptive approach to dealing with unstable behaviour of users in collaborative filtering systems

author-notes.corresp: Reza Rafeh, Department of Computer Engineering, Arak University, Arak, Iran. Email: R-Rafeh@araku.ac.ir

abstract.p: Recommendation systems manage information overload in order to present personalized content to users based on their interests. One of the most efficient recommendation approaches is collaborative filtering, through which recommendation is based on previously rated data. Collaborative filtering techniques feature impressive solutions for suggesting favourite items to certain users. However, recommendation methods fail to reflect fluctuations in users’ behaviour over time. In this article, we propose an adaptive collaborative filtering algorithm which takes time into account when predicting users’ behaviour. The transitive relationship from one user to another is considered when computing the similarity of two different users. We predict variations of users’ preferences using their profiles. Our experimental results show that the proposed algorithm is more accurate than the classical collaborative filtering technique.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: In the past few years, recommender systems have experienced a significant rise in the number of users due, in part, to information overload. Information overload is a widespread and rapidly growing phenomenon which refers to an incongruity between the amount of information, and the ability to process that information [1]. The most significant purpose of a recommender system is filtering the enormous quantity of available information to provide useful information based on the user’s interest. Recommendation systems are typically used for suggesting items such as books, music [2] and TV programs [3, 4] to certain users. Most existing recommendation techniques typically rely on the user’s long term profile [5]. The user’s profile holds metadata about his/her interests such as preferences and feedback – which may be implicit or explicit. During the recommendation process, if predictions are conducted based on knowledge of a similar group, the algorithm used is called collaborative filtering (CF). CF algorithms have been studied from two points of view: quality of predicting users’ preferences, and accuracy of ranking the content [6, 7]. CF algorithms are classified as memory-based and model-based [8]. Memory-based algorithms employ users’ ratings to measure the similarity between users and to predict their future behaviour. The most well-known recommendation methods are memory-based [9] CF which predict the ratings of active users based on neighbouring users [10]. Human behaviour may change macroscopically over time due to shifts in societal trends. If behaviour variation is more rapid than usual, the situation is characterized as a ‘mood swing’ and is ignored in this article.

In general, people have various reactions to events, and the interpretation of each action is dependent on its time and circumstances. The diversity of interests can be realized in the various factors which may be analysed by the system. The quantity and quality of simulations of these changes have a direct effect on the accuracy of the recommendation process. On the other hand, for some cases, each interaction has a particular meaning in a specific time period which may be interpreted differently in other time periods. Hence the time factor can play an important role in the calculations of recommender systems. An appropriate collaborative filtering algorithm should consider various factors to measure user similarity. Since each company has its own conditions and priorities, the CF algorithm must have the ability to adapt. As a result, an algorithm with acceptable performance in a system may not satisfy expectations of another system.

This article outlines a new collaborative filtering algorithm that has two outstanding features: time sensitivity and adaptability. The former tries to increase the prediction accuracy when time is considered as an effective factor in the system, while the latter adapts the algorithm to the management priorities of the target business.

The rest of this article is organized as follows: we begin by reviewing the related research studies in Section 2. In Section 3 the influence of time on the recommender system is analysed. Section 4 provides an explanation of our proposed approach. Section 5 presents the experiments carried out to evaluate our approach and Section 6 concludes with suggestions for future research.

sec.title: 2. Related work
sec.p: Collaborative filtering algorithms try to estimate the appropriateness of contents for a particular user based on what he and other users have done in the past [9]. Memory-based CF algorithms employ user–item datasets to make a recommendation. Every user is part of a group of people with similar interests [8]. A widely adopted approach in memory-based collaborative filtering is the k-nearest neighbour (KNN) algorithm. The prediction of a non-rated item i for a user u is computed as an aggregate rating of the k most similar users (k-neighbourhoods) for i. The training phase involves determining the most similar users/items (neighbourhoods) to the active user/item. In fact, this phase deals with selecting a subset of the user–item matrix for prediction [6, 7]. Another popular technique is top-N recommendation, which recommends a set of N top–sorted items for a target user based on its relevance [11]. Memory-based approaches have two obvious advantages: easy implementation, and adding new information about users/items with a low cost [9]. On the negative side, the accuracy decreases when using sparse data. The data sparsity that is a special form of the cold-start problem [12] occurs when a new item or user is added to the system. In this situation, organizing neighbourhoods is difficult since the system suffers from lack of sufficient information. In [8] an approach has been proposed which applies imputed relations between neighbours based on collaborative filtering algorithms that improve the performance of recommender systems for sparse data.

Tag-based recommendation systems have become an increasingly popular means for suggesting resources to users. One of the most significant recent studies in this area is [2], which utilizes implicit and explicit ratings to collect user preferences in mobile systems. Implicit ratings are computed by applying data mining methods to discover customer mobile web usage behaviour patterns in mobile web log data [13].

In order to enhance the performance of memory-based algorithms, model-based approaches have been introduced. Model-based approaches utilize some machine learning methods such as singular value decomposition [14], neural networks [15] and Bayesian networks [16, 17]. These types of CF algorithms improve the prediction accuracy. However, in some cases the cost of modelling is unexpected.

Hybrid CF techniques [18] combine collaborative filtering and content-based techniques [19, 20], with the aim of overcoming the limitations of other approaches. Although hybrid methods are recognized as a way to alleviate the scaling and sparsity problem, they do not find any optimized solution when the content of the environment changes dynamically.
In general, there are two critical processes which have a direct impact on the performance of collaborative filtering algorithm: measuring similarity and aggregation (making recommendations).

sec.title: 2.1. Measuring similarity
sec.p: A substantial part of the research in collaborative filtering has investigated finding the set of k users (neighbourhoods) similar to the target user u. Two users’ similarity determines how their activities are related to each other. The better the system can measure the similarity of users, the more accurate a prediction of the future behaviour for the target user is achieved. Although there are many similarity metrics, each metric concentrates only on one or two factors.

sec.title: 2.1.1. Pearson correlation coefficient similarity
sec.p: The most widely used metric is the Pearson correlation coefficient (PCC), which calculates the similarity between users based on their item ratings. sec.title: 2.3. Time-sensitive approaches
sec.p: A range of literature in the field of time-sensitive approaches focuses on users’ differing interests. For example, in [24] a hybrid collaborative filtering system has been proposed to alleviate issues with the interest differing problem, which uses a descending time-sensitive function to simulate user’s interests changing. The most relevant approach to this research is the study done in [6, 7], which analyses the temporal performance of CF algorithms. In this study, the impact of time on similarity, prediction and accuracy is measured. However, no clear way to overcome the time-passing-related problem is presented in the literature.

In other research, the history is divided into time intervals with different lengths, and similarity is computed in each interval separately [25]. However, the way of determining the initial time interval and the length of each time interval – which are considered the limitations of each system – is not described.

In [26], social tagging systems have been investigated, and tags and time have been used to predict users’ preferences. The authors have proposed three strategies to generate modified ratings using tag and time. Time–weight strategies are applied to deal with interest drifts through computing weight for each resource based on the time a user has bookmarked a resource.

An empirical study on mobile e-commerce environments has been conducted to analyse how the accuracy of recommendation systems depends on the temporal information. The focus of this research is to measure temporal behaviour by concentrating on item launch time, user purchase time, and the time interval between them [27]. Despite the significant progress in time-sensitive research, there is no common approach which can adapt itself to different conditions and situations of the system. In all the aforementioned methods, similarity is computed in the absence of any time pattern.

sec.title: 3. The influence of time on the result of recommendations
sec.p: As mentioned before, one of the major issues to enhance accuracy of collaborative filtering algorithms is considering the time factor in calculation. Consequently, tying the computation of prediction to time matter is essential. This subject can be analysed in several ways.

sec.title: 3.1. The similarity of users changes over time
sec.p: In each time stamp, new ratings or users are added to system, so new information may change the previous similarity of each pair of users. For example, suppose two high school students are outstanding in the same field, thus they are similar to each other in many aspects. After a period of time, they graduate from the school and continue their studies in different fields in the university. Thus, their subject interests change over time, which leads to changes in their similarity. Figure 1 illustrates an example from the MovieLens1 dataset, to show how similarity of user605 with user462 and user201 changes over time. The similarity measure is PCC.

caption.p: Changing similarity of users over time in MovieLens dataset.

sec.title: 3.2. Rating time and rating order
sec.p: As the behaviour of two users in two factors of rating time and rating order are more alike, more similarity will be considered between the two of them. According to Table 1, user u who is a student has purchased ‘Introduction to Programming’ from Amazon in the first timestamp. In the second timestamp they purchase ‘C# Programming’ and ‘Advanced Programming by C#’ in the third. Now, in the fourth timestamp they have graduated from university and in the fifth they search for ‘Online Programming Job’. Let’s look at another user of the system, who buys both ‘C# programming’ and ‘Advanced programming by C#’ in the fourth timestamp. Until the fourth timestamp these two users have similar histories in the aspect of purchased item type. But can we strictly recommend ‘Online Programming Job’ to the second user? They have dissimilar behaviour in view of purchasing timestamp which interacts with the system. By analysing the timestamp sequence of the first user, a fact can be inferred: they have purchased books in a regular schedule (for example, in each semester he passed a course which related to a purchased book). Therefore, probably he is a student who has graduated recently and is now looking for a job, whilst for a second user maybe he is a java programmer who has some knowledge about the basis of programming (because he did not purchase ‘Introduction to Programming’) and now wants to become acquainted with C#. Consequently, if they have each bought a book in identical timestamps, then the probability of similarity will increase. Briefly, by increasing the time distance of common items between two users, the similarity will decrease.

sec.title: 3.3. Recent interactions
sec.p: In general, people’s priorities always are changing. Users may dislike the items which they rated highly in the past. For example, a young couple had their first baby 2 years ago and they were interested in items such as parental education, baby-related safe feeders, recipes, food etc. When their baby becomes 2 years old, this couple may be interested in things other than those for new-born babies [24]. Therefore, recent interactions have a great effect on predicting current requirements of users.

In order to implement various aspects of time factors in our algorithm, we modify existing collaborative filtering algorithms in two phases: computing similarity and making recommendations. In each level we propose particular adaptive formulas that have the ability of changing their parameters with respect to limitations of target business.

sec.title: 4. Proposed approach
sec.p: We use the standard notation to describe CF problems. The input can be structured as an m×n binary matrix A. With customers = {u1, u1,…, um} and n items I = {i1, i1,…, in}, au,I = 1 means that there is a transaction between u and i (for example, u has purchased i) and au,I = 0 otherwise [28, 29]. Our algorithm consists of four main steps:

list-item.p: Creating the user–item graph which corresponds to the user–item matrix.
Calculating similarity of direct neighbourhoods, which aggregates the differences between the behaviours of two users.
Measuring similarity of the active user and all other users.

sec.title: 4.1. Creating user–item graph
sec.p: The aim of creating the user–item graph is to simplify understanding of the relations between users who interact with the system. Based on the user–item matrix, we define an undirected graph (U, E) in which U = {u1, u1,…, um} is the set of users who have rated at least one item and {ui,uj}∈E means that there is least one item in common between ui,uj∈U,ui≠uj . Edges are labelled to determine the similarity between users. For each user there are two kinds of neighbours: direct neighbour and indirect neighbour. Direct neighbours are connected to the active user by a direct edge. The path between indirect neighbours and the active user includes more than one edge. Figure 2 shows a sample user–item graph that corresponds to matrix A, whose rows correspond to users and columns to items.

sec.title: 4.2. Calculating similarity of direct neighbours
sec.p: In this step the distance between two direct neighbours is calculated. The more similar two users are in their history, the higher weight will be assigned to the edge between them. In our previous research we proposed a time-sensitive similarity metric for calculating the similarity of two users when they have at least one shared item [29]. We use this metric for calculating the weight of two direct neighbours in the proposed algorithm. We give a brief description of the similarity metric in the following.

Our proposed metric takes into account new factors such as time of interactions and order of interactions. The adaptability of our algorithm can be seen in the way it combines different parameters considering the importance of each aspect for the target system. Two users are comparable from four points of view:

list-item.p: the number of common purchased items;
the degree of users’ interest in common items;

sec.p: Considering the limitations and goals of the target business, the effect of each factor on the final weight for edges is determined. For example, when there is no appropriate rating definition to evaluate the user’s degree of interest for a specific item, the number of common purchased items plays a more important role. When the system and users have fluctuating behaviour in various time intervals, the timestamp of the rated items becomes more important. It is clear that when two users are exactly identical in all aspects, the weight of their edge is the maximum. But when they are not quite identical in all aspects we employ a standard method to measure the weight. We explain the effect of the above factors by means of an example.

sec.title: 4.3. Measuring the similarity between the active user and indirect neighbours
sec.p: In the previous step, the strength of the relationship between behaviours of two direct neighbours has been determined. In this section the similarity of the active user with all other users having a possible path is determined. To calculate the similarity between the active user and an indirect neighbour, an extended version of direct similarity measuring is employed which uses the ideas of regular equivalence [30] and transitive similarity [31]. Relations in Figure 3 state a transitive similarity between users, i.e. if user u1 is similar to user u2 and u2 is similar to u3, we can say u1 and u3 are similar, although the similarity of u1 and u3 is less than the similarity of u1 and u2, as well as the similarity of u2 and u3.

sec.p: The algorithm depicted in Figure 7 illustrates the workflow of computing similarity. It gets the user–item graph and a user u as input and calculates the similarity of u with all other users.

sec.p: We use two queues Qa and Qb. The former holds nodes (users) that must be traced to calculate their similarity with u, and the latter holds users whose similarities with u have already been measured. There is no intersection between queues. When a user is removed from Qa, it is added to Qb immediately. In each iteration of the while loop, a user is removed from Qa and its direct neighbours’ similarity with u is calculated.

To insert a user into Qa, two conditions must be met: first, the user must not be in either Qa or in Qb. Second, the similarity between the user and u must be greater than MaxSim/µ (µ is an integer greater than one). The second condition is used to control the execution time of the algorithm. The question is how the second condition influences of the algorithm performance.

As we mentioned earlier, one of the most widespread algorithms in the field of memory-based approaches is k-nearest neighbours, in which, after calculating the similarity between active user and others, k neighbours are selected as the most similar users to make recommendations. In our algorithm, the active user has direct and indirect relationships to many other users. As the length of the path between the active user and another user is increased, often the score of similarity is decreased. On the other hand, the users with trivial similarity do not play a significant role in predicting the behaviour of the active user in the future. Therefore, the second condition helps us to avoid tracing disappointed paths and optimize calculations.

sec.title: 4.4. Making recommendations
sec.p: In this step, the system makes recommendations for all users. Predicting the behaviour of the active user means proposing the most relevant items to him/her. In each system the type of recommendation can be different depending on the types of users and items. Our algorithm estimates an active user’s interest in items not rated by him/her yet. The estimation depends on the relation between the active user and all the other users. Prediction in the algorithm needs two factors:

list-item.p: the interest of neighbours in the items not rated by the active user;
the distance between the timestamp of rating and the current timestamp.

sec.title: 5. Experiments and evaluation
sec.p: To evaluate the proposed algorithm we used MovieLens1 and Amazon5 data sets. We divided each dataset into two sections: one for training and the other for testing. The training subset was used for computing the similarity of users. Then, the predicted ratings obtained from the training subset were compared with real users’ ratings in the test subset.

The results of the proposed algorithm are compared with the classical collaborative filtering algorithm. Experiments show that the proposed approach is more accurate when the training set reflects all aspects of users’ behaviour.

sec.title: 5.1. Metrics
sec.p: We used two kinds of metrics for evaluating the accuracy:

Statistical accuracy metrics: Such metrics evaluate the accuracy by comparison with the predicted rates with real rates [32, 33]. Mean absolute error (MAE) is a widespread method falling into this category and is used in our experiments:
where pi,j is the predicted rate for item i by user j and ri,j is the real rate. A lower value for MAE means the predictions are more accurate.

Decision support accuracy metrics: Such metrics evaluate how effective is a collaborative filtering method with proposing high-quality items to the user from the set of all items. The Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) method is chosen to measure the diagnostic power of a CF system [34]. This metric assumes the ratings are labelled either as positive (p) or negative (n) class. According to this binary classifier, there are four possible states. If both predicted and real rates are p, the state is TP; when the predicted rate is n and the real rate is p, the state is FP. TN means that the predicted and real rates are n, and finally FN means that predicted and real rates are p. In our experiments, the accuracy of the method, using ROC, is measured via (23), in which a rating is p if its value is greater than 3 and otherwise is n:
A higher value for ROC means a high quality prediction.

sec.p: It is generally argued that, by increasing the size of the sample training dataset (number of ratings), the system learns more about the behaviour of users. Consequently, by decreasing the size, the results are more error-prone in predicting the exact value of items’ rates. However, our results indicate that there is no strong relationship between the size and accuracy. What is more important is whether a group of similar users resides in a sample or not. A user may have more friends in a certain sample dataset in comparison to the other one. For instance, although the size of sample 6 is less than the size of sample 2, MAE of sample 2 is greater than for sample 6.

sec.title: 6. Conclusions and future work
sec.p: The most important purpose of a recommender system is filtering the enormous quantity of available information to extract information based on the user interest. In this article we investigated the effect of time on predicting the behaviour of users. We proposed an approach for calculating users’ similarity considering the time factor, which had two major attributes – time sensitivity and adaptivity.

First and foremost, it considered time as an effective factor in calculating similarity and recommendation processes. The second attribute is adaptivity, which means, by consideration of the conditions of business and type of items and users, some variables change to improve the accuracy of predictions. Our experimental results show that the accuracy of our algorithm is higher than classical collaborative filtering algorithms when the frequency of changing users’ behaviour is high.

In the future, by using the history of interactions, we intend to calculate the weights automatically. In addition, to enhance the performance of collaborative filtering algorithms, new information sources must be taken into account, such as social relationships [35, 36]. This helps us to enrich the user–item graph in a more exact way by augmenting the user profile and considering the explicit relationship between one user and others.
